blocks.label: The Good King
blocks.english: All Is Good Â· No Category of 'Bad'
blocks.tagline: The deepest secret of Purim: there is no category of 'bad' in the world at all. Everythingâ€”absolutely everythingâ€”comes from the Good King and is therefore good. Haman's every scheme became Israel's salvation.

details.title: The Purim Revelation
details.content: What appears evil is actually concealed good. Every scheme of Haman turned into salvation for Israel. The day he chose by lot for destruction became our greatest celebration. This isn't just historyâ€”it's a template for viewing all of life.

details.title: Tanna D'Bei Eliyahu
details.content: The teaching: 'It was for my benefit that my cow's leg broke.' When something apparently bad happens, think: this is actually good. We must believe that all events come from the Creator, the Good King.

details.title: The Power of This Recognition
details.content: When a person deeply internalizes that all apparent evil transforms to goodâ€”this very thinking purifies their consciousness. Every circumstance that appears bad, when one says ×’× ×–×• ×œ×˜×•×‘×”, will actually turn to good.

blocks.label: Ad D'Lo Yada
blocks.english: Until One Doesn't Know Â· Beyond Categories
blocks.tagline: We must become intoxicated 'until one doesn't know between cursed is Haman and blessed is Mordechai'â€”meaning: reaching the recognition that both categories are actually good.

details.title: First Interpretation
details.content: There is no distinction between the 'cursed Haman' category (things that appear evil) and the 'blessed Mordechai' category (things that appear good). They are ALL goodâ€”there is no evil whatsoever from the Good King.

details.title: Second Interpretation
details.content: When a wicked person intends evil but good comes from their actions, that good emerges 'without their ×“×¢×ª'â€”like a drunk who doesn't know what they're doing. The good was not their intention, yet God transformed it anyway.

details.title: The Drunk as Metaphor
details.content: A drunk acts without conscious intent. Similarly, evil-doers produce good 'without their knowledge.' Events that appear negative are actually for our benefitâ€”we simply cannot perceive the good, like being intoxicated to reality.

blocks.label: Purim & Shavuot
blocks.tagline: Just as Shavuot celebrates receiving Torah at Sinai, Purim celebrates re-accepting Torah from love of the miracle. Both days require physical joy because Torah is a gift we treasure.

details.title: Why Mar the Son of Ravina Didn't Fast
details.content: He fasted the entire year except for Shavuot and Purim. On Shavuot, we rejoice to show Torah is pleasant and accepted. On Purim, we rejoice because Israel re-accepted Torah from loveâ€”and this re-acceptance is dear to us.

details.title: The Meal Must Be During the Day
details.content: Torah was given openly, in daylightâ€”'I did not speak from the beginning in secret.' Since Purim's essence is re-accepting Torah, the seudah must likewise be during the day, not at night.

details.title: How to Conduct the Seudah
details.content: Don't engage in foolish behavior. Rather, accept the yoke of Torah and mitzvot anew. With every ×›×–×™×ª you eat, intend that you're rejoicing in Torah and mitzvot, just as in the days of Mordechai and Esther.

blocks.label: Elevation of Sparks
blocks.english: Sparks from the Kelipot Â· Ba'al Teshuvah Joy
blocks.tagline: The holy sparks trapped within Haman and Achashverosh were elevated through the miracle. This is why wine is requiredâ€”wine represents the joy of the ×‘×¢×œ ×ª×©×•×‘×”, the greatest joy of all.

details.title: Sparks in Achashverosh
details.content: Even though Achashverosh was wicked, he decreed to hang Haman and avenged Israel. Because God manipulated him to do good, he merited that his son Darius would build the Second Temple! There were × ×™×¦×•×¦×•×ª ×§×“×•×©×” within him.

details.title: Sparks in Haman
details.content: Though his intention was evil, salvation came through his deeds. He prepared the gallows on which he was hung. His advice to kill Vashti led to Esther becoming queen. His descendants taught Torah to the massesâ€”the 'Bnei Barak.'

details.title: Why the Greater Joy
details.content: The delight from elevating sparks trapped in ×§×œ×™×¤×•×ª is greater than from tzaddikim. Like a son who visits from a distant placeâ€”the delight is greater than from a son always present. Hence we increase wine-drinking.

blocks.label: Drawing Down Blessing
blocks.english: Publicizing the Miracle Â· Activating the Energy
blocks.tagline: When we recount the miracle through reading the Megillah and rejoicing, we activate that same miraculous energy for today. We draw down the same type of salvation into our current circumstances.

details.title: Why Retelling Matters
details.content: When we recount a miracle, that miracle continues to shine for us. By telling the story and celebrating, we draw down the same type of salvationâ€”the Purim-type miracle where enemies are compelled to do good.

details.title: What We Need in Galut
details.content: During exile, we especially need this type of miracle: the hearts of nations inclined toward us, rulers doing good with us. Since we live under foreign dominion, we publicize the Purim miracle to draw down this influence.

details.title: Intention While Eating
details.content: During eating and drinking, intend that the nations should do good with us. Pray that anyone who wants to do evilâ€”from that very act, great good should sprout forth, just as with Haman's schemes.

items.description: Miracles that CHANGE natureâ€”splitting the sea, the ten plagues.
items.detail: God saved us through supernatural wonders that altered the very fabric of creation. This is open, revealed salvation. Reminds us that even when the world operates 'naturally,' God transcends natural law.

items.description: Victory THROUGH battleâ€”the few over the many.
items.detail: God gave the holy ones power over their enemies through military victory. This is salvation through human effort empowered by God. When we must fight, God gives us strength.

items.description: Enemies COMPELLED to do goodâ€”the most remarkable of all.
items.detail: God placed into the hearts of our very enemies the thoughts and actions that became our salvation. The wicked themselves, against their will, did good for Israel. Most relevant in galut.

blocks.title: Understanding the Intoxication
blocks.intro: The requirement to drink 'until one doesn't know' has two profound interpretations:

items.content: Everything Is Good: Reach the recognition that there's no real distinction between 'bad' (cursed Haman category) and 'good' (blessed Mordechai category). All is actually good from the Good King.
Good Without Intent: Evil-doers produce good 'without their ×“×¢×ª' (knowledge/intent)â€”like a drunk who doesn't know what they're doing. The good was not their intention, yet it emerged anyway.
Beyond Comprehension: Events that appear negative are for our benefitâ€”we simply cannot perceive the good. The benefit comes 'without our ×“×¢×ª,' beyond our understanding, like being intoxicated.

blocks.outro: This is the illumination of Purim: from all of Haman's evil schemes came only good. We internalize that from the Good King, only good can come.

rows.result: Prepared his own gallows, Esther became queen

blocks.intro: Why is there greater obligation to drink wine on Purim than other holidays?

items.content: Holy Sparks Elevated: The sparks trapped within Haman and Achashverosh experienced great elevation through Purim. Though wicked, their actions became vehicles for holiness.
Ba'al Teshuvah Joy: The delight from elevating sparks from ×§×œ×™×¤×•×ª is greater than from tzaddikim. Like a son who visits from afarâ€”the joy is greater than from a son always present.
Wine = Joy: Since Purim has elevation of sparks from within the ×§×œ×™×¤×”â€”great joy like that of a ×‘×¢×œ ×ª×©×•×‘×”â€”we must increase our joy. Wine is the ×¡×•×“ (secret) of joy.

blocks.outro: Wine also hints to the seventy members of the Sanhedrin HaGedolah who were in the World of Delight.

items.title: Transform Your Perspective
items.body: When something apparently bad happens, your immediate response should be: 'This is actually goodâ€”I just can't see how yet.' Say 'gam zu l'tovah' and mean it. This recognition actually draws down the good.

items.title: The Purim Seudah
items.body: Don't just feastâ€”accept Torah anew. With every bite, intend that you're celebrating the yoke of Torah and mitzvot. The meal must be during the day. Avoid foolish behaviorâ€”the joy should be 'in Hashem.'

items.title: Drawing Down Blessing
items.body: When reading the Megillah, you're not just remembering historyâ€”you're activating miraculous energy for today. Have in mind that nations among whom we live should have their hearts inclined toward our good.

items.title: Sparks from Unlikely Sources
items.body: There is potential holiness everywhere. Even from the most unlikely sourcesâ€”people who seem far from goodnessâ€”blessing can emerge. When you see good from unexpected places, rejoice with ba'al teshuvah joy.

blocks.content:
Purim reveals the deepest secret of Divine providence: there is no category of 'bad' in the world at all. Everything comes from the Good King, and therefore everythingâ€”even what appears evilâ€”is actually good. Haman's every scheme became Israel's salvation. The day he chose for destruction became our greatest celebration.

This is why we must drink 'until we don't know between cursed Haman and blessed Mordechai'â€”because ultimately there is no difference. Both categories are good. The evil-doer produces good 'without their knowledge,' and we benefit 'without our comprehension.' But the truth remains: from the Good King, only good can come.

May we merit to truly internalize this teaching, saying ×’× ×–×• ×œ×˜×•×‘×” not as empty words but as deep recognition. And may our difficulties be transformed into revealed blessings, just as every scheme of Haman became Israel's salvation.
